natural problem:
The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$.
natural solution: We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$

We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "distinct (map r [1..2007])"
and h2 : "set (map r [1..2007]) = {x. f x = 0}"
and h3 : "\<forall> j \<in> set [1..2007]. P(r j + 1/r j) = 0"
and h4 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P(- 1) = 289 / 259"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "distinct (map r [1..2007])"
and h2 : "set (map r [1..2007]) = {x. f x = 0}"
and h3 : "\<forall> j \<in> set [1..2007]. P(r j + 1/r j) = 0"
and h4 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P(- 1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Assume a function $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and another function $P$. We know that $f(x)$ has 2007 distinct roots, which are denoted by $r(1)$, $r(2)$, ..., $r(2007)$. Moreover, for each root $r(j)$, $P(r(j) + \frac{1}{r(j)}) = 0$. The degree of $P$ is 2007. Find the ratio $P(1) / P(-1)$. The final answer is $289 / 259$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "degree f = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "degree f = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A function $f(x)$ is defined by $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and it has a degree of 2007. For every integer $j$ from 1 to 2007, $P\left(\frac{r(j) + 1}{r(j)}\right) = 0$. What is the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$? The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. f (r j) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h3 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. f (r j) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h3 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a polynomial $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and a polynomial $P$ of degree 2007, find the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$ if $f(rj) = 0$ and $P(rj + 1/rj) = 0$ for all $j$ between 1 and 2007, inclusive. The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"

and h2 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}

 *)

theorem
fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h2 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"

a_3.informal problem: Let $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and $P(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2007 such that $P(r_j + \frac{1}{r_j}) = 0$ for every $j$ from 1 to 2007. Find the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h2 : "degree P = 2007"
and h3 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> f (r j) = 0 \<and> r j \<noteq> 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h2 : "degree P = 2007"
and h3 : "\<forall> j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> f (r j) = 0 \<and> r j \<noteq> 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and a polynomial $P$ of degree 2007. For every integer $j$ from 1 to 2007, the polynomial $P$ has roots at $r_j + \frac{1}{r_j}$ where $r_j$ are the roots of $f$. If $f(r_j) = 0$ for all these $j$ and $r_j \neq 0$, what is the ratio of $P(1)$ to $P(-1)$? The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "degree P = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall>j. j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "degree P = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall>j. j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a polynomial function $P(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ with degree 2007, and a sequence of real numbers $r(j)$ such that for all $j$ up to 2007, $P(r(j) + 1/r(j)) = 0$, find the ratio of $P(1)$ to $P(-1)$. The final answer is $289/259$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..2007} \<longrightarrow> f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..2007} \<longrightarrow> P (r i + 1 / r i) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..2007} \<longrightarrow> f (r i) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<in> {1..2007} \<longrightarrow> P (r i + 1 / r i) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$. There are 2007 real numbers $r_i$ such that $f(r_i) = 0$. Let $P(x)$ be another function such that $P(r_i + \frac{1}{r_i}) = 0$ for all $i$ in the set ${1, 2, ..., 2007}$. Find the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real => real" and P :: "real => real" and r :: "nat => real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. j \<ge> 1 \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h2 : "card {r j | j. j \<ge> 1 \<and> j \<le> 2007} = 2007"
and h3 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (- 1) = 289 / 259"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real => real" and P :: "real => real" and r :: "nat => real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> j. j \<ge> 1 \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
and h2 : "card {r j | j. j \<ge> 1 \<and> j \<le> 2007} = 2007"
and h3 : "degree P = 2007"
shows  "P 1 / P (- 1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and a polynomial $P$ of degree 2007. Suppose we have a sequence of real numbers $r_j$ such that for each $j$ from 1 to 2007, $P(r_j + 1/r_j) = 0$. Furthermore, suppose that there are exactly 2007 distinct numbers in the set $\{r_j\}$ for $j$ from 1 to 2007. What is the ratio $P(1) / P(-1)$? The final answer is $289 / 259$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2007"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> poly P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "degree f = 2007"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 2007 \<longrightarrow> poly P (r j + 1 / r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: For a polynomial $f$ of degree $2007$ such that $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$, and a sequence $r$ such that for all $j$ from $1$ to $2007$, the polynomial $P$ evaluated at $r(j) + \frac{1}{r(j)}$ is $0$, find the ratio of $P(1)$ to $P(-1)$. The final answer is $\frac{289}{259}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "card {r_i. \<exists> i \<in> {1..2007}. r i = r_i \<and> f r_i = 0} = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = poly [r i + 1/r i | i \<leftarrow> [1..2007]] x"
and h3 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1/r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $f(x)=x^{2007}+17x^{2006}+1$ has distinct zeroes $r_1,\ldots,r_{2007}$.  A polynomial $P$ of degree $2007$ has the property that
\[P\left(r_j+\dfrac{1}{r_j}\right)=0\]for $j=1,\ldots,2007$.  Determine the value of $\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)}$. The final Answer is \frac{289}{259}
 ### Proof
 We can write \[f(x) = (x - r_1)(x - r_2) \dotsm (x - r_{2017})\]and \[P(z) = k \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( z - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)\]for some nonzero constant $k.$
 We want to compute \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( 1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} \left( -1 - \left( r_j + \frac{1}{r_j} \right) \right)} = \frac{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1)}{\prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1)}.\]Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^2 + x + 1 = 0,$ so
 \[x^2 + x + 1 = (x - \alpha)(x - \beta).\]Then \[x^2 - x + 1 = (x + \alpha)(x + \beta).\]Also, $(\alpha - 1)(\alpha^2 + \alpha + 1) = \alpha^3 - 1 = 0,$ so $\alpha^3 = 1.$  Similarly, $\beta^3 = 1.$  Thus, \begin{align}
 \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 - r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j + \alpha)(r_j + \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (-\alpha - r_j)(-\beta - r_j) \\ &= f(-\alpha) f(-\beta) \\ &= (-\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(-\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\
 &= (17 \alpha^2)(17 \beta^2) \\ &= 289. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j^2 + r_j + 1) &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (r_j - \alpha)(r_j - \beta) \\ &= \prod_{j = 1}^{2007} (\alpha - r_j)(\beta - r_j) \\
 &= f(\alpha) f(\beta) \\ &= (\alpha^{2007} + 17 \alpha^{2006} + 1)(\beta^{2007} + 17 \beta^{2006} + 1) \\ &= (17 \alpha^2 + 2)(17 \beta^2 + 2) \\ &= 289 \alpha^2 \beta^2 + 34 \alpha^2 + 34 \beta^2 + 4 \\
 &= 259. \end{align}Therefore, \[\frac{P(1)}{P(-1)} = \boxed{\frac{289}{259}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x powr 2007 + 17 * x powr 2006 + 1"
and h1 : "card {r_i. \<exists> i \<in> {1..2007}. r i = r_i \<and> f r_i = 0} = 2007"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = poly [r i + 1/r i | i \<leftarrow> [1..2007]] x"
and h3 : "\<forall> j \<in> {1..2007}. P (r j + 1/r j) = 0"
shows  "P 1 / P (-1) = 289 / 259"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = x^{2007} + 17x^{2006} + 1$ and another function $P(x)$ defined as the polynomial with roots $r_i + 1/r_i$ where $r_i$ are the 2007 roots of the function $f$. If all the roots $r_i$ of $f$ also make $P(r_i + 1/r_i) = 0$, find the ratio $P(1) / P(-1)$. The final answer is $289 / 259$.
